text:
More like 4 and a half stars.  A tad on the sweet side (should have listened to reviews and cut back on sugar some), but still so so yummy.  Seemed dry when first put together, but it really creams up quickly in the frig - 2 hours is plenty of time for it to set up.  I added two diced radishes, I think next time I will add four, to help the sweet factor and to add some more crunch.  Aftter reading reviews, I added more onion, ground mustard and a tad more salt.  Yummers!  Served with ribs and baked beans.  My boyfriend's take:  "better than Southern cooking and I never had to leave my porch in Arizona."  And he is picky about his slaw.  POSTSCRIPT:  I cut back on the sugar the next time, and it just didn't taste as good.  I tried adding the sugar back in after I had already added the slaw -- didn't really work.

text:
This is very good- almost the my family's long time recipe. One thing I do to make it creamier and less watery- I only put half the dressing on it  to begin with. After an hour, I drain some of the dressing off, and then put the rest on- make a little extra dressing if needed. After you put any vinegar based dressing on cabbage, some of it's water will leach out, making it soupy- this makes it creamier.

text:
This is very much like the slaw we make in our deli and people come from other counties just to get this slaw.  I tried cutting down the ingredients from the huge amount we make at the store and it comes out to very much like this recipe.  Except we don't use any oil in our dressing.  You don't need it.  Just added calories.  We use a good mayonaisse instead of salad dressing and our slaw dressing would come out to 1 cup of mayo, 2/3 cup sugar and 2.5 tablespoons white vinegar.  About 1.5 pounds of shredded cabbage and one shredded carrot.  We don't use onions in our slaw although some probably would like that.  I would probably use a good sweet onion like a Vadalia maybe.  I'm thinking I'd also use celery seed instead of poppy seeds.  We use celery seed in our pickled slaw and it's good!  Letting it sit a while is the key.  That loosens up the dressing.  Just remember to stir it good before serving.

text:
I'm giving it 5-stars even though I didn't follow the recipe exactly but close enough....In the morning I shredded & chopped 1/2 cabbage (=1 pound) & 1 carrot, upped the onion closer to 3 Tablespoons, very finely diced & let that sit together in the fridge for a coupla hours. Just before noon I followed the dressing recipe (btw, the directions do not specifically say to use Miracle Whip, it's merely a suggestion & I suspect the ones who complain about this being too sweet probably did use Miracle Whip), using mayo, left out the poppy seeds (I never have them in my cupboard nor did we like it when we sub'd celery seed) & added a dash of fresh ground black pepper. After 4 hours in the fridge this was great on it's own but BOMB over slow smoked pulled pork!!! I can't stop thinking about it & I don't even like cole slaw! Can't wait to see how much better it probably tastes today!!!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the recipe that made me a fan of coleslaw. I had been making coleslaw for my husband for years but never cared for it. From the first time I used this recipe I have nibbled from each and every batch :)

I make the recipe almost as written except that for personal preference I use mayo instead of creamy salad dressing and a packet of Splenda instead of white sugar. 

A couple of tips: combine everything except the coleslaw mix in a large bowl until smooth and blended. Taste and adjust until you like the taste of the dressing. Stir in the coleslaw mix a bit at a time. It will seem dry at first but don't worry - after a couple hours in the fridge (covered) it will be deliciously creamy and you can move it to a smaller container.

Finally, and I can't stress this enough, use the nicest vinegar and oil in your pantry. You will really taste the difference. If it doesn't taste nice on your finger, it will not improve once you've added it to the bowl. I use white balsamic vinegar and a light salad oil or almond oil - the type you would use to make a salad dressing.

This coleslaw is excellent on hamburgers, with BBQ'd anything, on pizza (yes, pizza!) and just by itself. Thanks for posting it, Sandi.

text:
Just finished making a double recipe of slaw for 2 parties today. (gota love being retired in Hawaii!!) Tasted it before the rest in the fridge and I'm here to say this is one "broke da mout" "Ono" slaw! The onions do add a wonderful layer of flavor to this recipe that I wouldn't have thought to try. If you make this for a party, you may as well double it, because it won't last long. What I did for a double recipe: 1) 3# Head of cabbage, 4+TBS) onions, 1 1/3cups) Mayo, 5 TBS) vegetable oil, 2/3cups) sugar, 4TBS) white vinegar, 1/2 tsp) Salt, and 1 tsp) poppy seeds.  I tasted my store bought (Kraft) stand by to compare, and found that this recipe wasn't quite as sweet as what I've been using. I always like the KFC slaw but now, It's this or nothing for this guy! ****UPDATE**** Next time I make this I'm not going to add the wet ingredients to the slaw until just before I leave for a function. As I mentioned above, the flavor was very good when I first added the dressing. After two hours the dressing broke the cabbage down to the point that it was swimming in juice. Didn't look real appetizing at all but still tasted good. I noticed a couple people poke at the juice in the bowl and walk away. Still keeping it at 5 stars though!*****UPDATE 9/12) Made this salad again today. I used less of the sauce on this salad and still there was more than enough to make a great slaw. Next time I'm going to cut the dressing in half. I'm sure it will still be a 5 star recipe with less waste!

text:
This is a delicious slaw recipe and one I've been using since 2007.  It gets rave reviews anytime I make it for family or friends.  I have made it both as the original recipe and also with my changes.

  I've found that my family prefers it when I use onion powder instead of the fresh onion added in - but if using fresh onion, the sweet onion that is finely chopped works best for flavor.  

Also I prefer apple cider vinegar instead of white vinegar in the recipe.  For the vegetable oil I use extra virgin olive oil.  Only thing I add that isn't in the recipe is some black pepper. 

This is a great slaw recipe and one that is better than any of the slaw dressings that are available at the store.

country:
None
text:
With the exception of the sweetness, this is very close to the coleslaw I make to duplicate the way my mom made coleslaw when I was a kid.  Her method was to put your sugar in a measuring cup, then pour apple cider vinegar over the sugar until it is saturated.  This, in my opinion, creates the best balance of sweet & sour.  One additional thing I do to get better crunch is to soak your grated cabbage in ice water for about 30-60 minutes, then drain well before mixing in your dressing. I also add grated carrot (as the picture shows) for color.  The creaminess increases as the mixture sits.  A tad of sour cream can be added to adjust the sweetness if needed.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/681695.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is similar to our traditional family coleslaw recipe.  We grind our cabbage by using an old fashioned hand grinder (use the fine blade).  With the ground cabbage in a large bowl, we sprinkle about 2 Tablespoons of sugar and 1 Tablespoon of black pepper on top, mix, cover, and let stand for 2 or 3 hours.  WHY?  To draw the water out of the cabbage.  Then we drain the liquid, add a generous amount of regular mayonnaise and blend all ingredients together.  It is a German recipe, with logical processes and simple ingredients.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is almost like my moms.  We start out with 1 head of cabbage (shredded), 3 Tbls. of grated onion, 1/2 - 2/3 C. Miracle Whip, 1 Capful of Apple Cider Vinegar, 1/4 tsp. celery seed, 3 grated carrots, 1 Tbls. milk.........mix together....sprinkle 3 Tablespoons of sugar on top and let set in refrigerator for at least 2 hours.  Mix all together and serve.  OMG.........so flippen good:) Enjoy.  Thanks mom.....she's in heaven, now.

country:

text:
This is a fantastic basic recipe.  I am a KFC cole slaw junkie, but even as much as I love the KFC (price notwithstanding), I always felt it was WAY too sweet.  Based on the other reviews, I did the following: used the bagged slaw mix, used mayo rather than Miracle Whip, 2T EVOO, 1/4 cup sugar, upped the vinegar to 2T and replaced the poppy seeds with an equal amount of celery seeds (1/2 t).  OMG... this has only been in the fridge for 2 hours and I just tasted it... INCREDIBLE.  SO much better than the KFC.  This is the recipe I've been looking for.  My German auntie Em was known for her cole slaw, and it's an exact duplicate of hers.  This will go into my regular rotation, and I can't WAIT to put this on my newfound pulled pork recipe. I am SO in awe of having found this recipe.  Next time I will double the recipe... the cabbage shrinks a bunch as it marinates. Thankyou Sandi! P.S.  Make sure you really well whisk the dressing... that sugar can lurk into the corners of your container.  Final thought...

U-N-B-E-L-I-E-V-A-B-L-E! With a passion for cooking and the nickname "country chef" by friends, there aren't many recipes or dishes that I can't perfect. Cole slaw is one of the few I struggle with. I've watched my mother-in-law and grandmother make delicious coleslaw countless times and tried so many different recipes. I'm not the measuring type and I have been stumped many times. I could never get it just right. 
Now this is my recipe of choice and everone loves it and many ask for the recipe. It is so delicious and easy.
So good I would give it more stars if I could. The only changes I made were: 1)use celery seed instead of poppy seeds and 2)cut the sugar in half.

I didn't have coleslaw mix, so I initially passed this recipe and looked for others, but of all the ones I looked through this one had the best reviews and best looking ingredient list. I was worried about the amount of cabbage for the ratio of dressing but a medium sized cabbage and a few grated carrots worked out perfectly. I didn't change anything and the flavor was great. It's not often that you read so many reviews that say the recipe is perfect "as-is". 

It was also helpful to hear from another reviewer that the dressing builds up after it sits for a few hours, that was something that was an initial concern, but everything worked out perfectly. This recipe is definitely a keeper.

text:
I love this dressing! I used one pre-packaged bag of coleslaw mix. I did make minor adjustments to the ingredients. I used sour cream instead of veg oil, 2 T rice wine vinegar ( it's all I had on hand) and also I cut back on the white suagr to 1/4 cup. I like sweet but not too sweet.  I marinated for about 4 hours. The results were amazing. I used celery seeds instead of poppy seeds and found that this added nice texture to the coleslaw. The marinade was sweet but too sweet and with nice flavor. With adjustments that I made, this turned out to be a tasty coleslaw!

text:
Great cole slaw base!  Quick, easy, yummy, and adaptable:  What's not to like?  I heeded advice from other reviewers and cut the sugar in half (actually, I used Splenda -- can't tell the diff).  I also replaced the oil with water to thin it out without adding more fat.  The flavors are great; I'd never put onion in slaw before, but it's quite nice.  In my opinion, white vinegar, apple cider vinegar, and rice wine vinegar are all lovely with this recipe.  Give them a try.

0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM YUM YUMMY!!! The best coleslaw recipe I have found :-) I made the following changes as suggested by other users: 1. Add 2 tbsp. apple cider vinegar instead of the 1 tbsp. of white vinegar 2. Only used 1/4 of a cup of sugar and it was plenty sweet 3. Subtract the vegetable oil (delicious without it it would be real oily if you add it) 4. Instead of the bagged stuff I used 1 small head of green cabbage and a little less than 1/2 of red cabbage with 1 large shredded carrot still cheaper than the pre-cut stuff 5. Subtract the poppy seeds - I don't have them on hand - Add heaping 1/4 tsp. of celery seeds. 6. Add a dash of pepper 7. Instead of letting it all marinate I found it to be fresher and more delicious by waiting to add the dressing until right before serving. It's just a really great fresh taste and this is a great base recipe to get ideas then to make your own changes for your own prefrence. But I will SOOOOOOOOO make this recipe again and can't wait for an excuse to make it again. 5 big delicious stars!
Review:

text:
I really wanted to make this a little healthier, if I could. I used broccoli slaw and added about 3/4 c. of shredded carrots. I used half mayo, half fat free PLAIN yogurt and cut the sugar to two tablespoons. The recipe didn't specify what kind of onion, so I used green onions. We all enjoyed this. I think I might add more green onion next time. The longer this sets, the better it is. I plan on serving the leftovers on ham sandwiches for the fam tomorrow, mine will be in a bowl with chopped ham, sans bread.

text:
Great coleslaw recipe. Reminiscent of St-Hubert's creamy coleslaw, but a little sweeter.

Keep in mind that the coleslaw will appear alarmingly dry when mixing in the sauce with the slaw.  But after sitting in the fridge for a few hours, the sauce thickened up quite nicely.  

Only alterations I made were to add some pepper to taste and a tsp of mustard.

Loved this! I cut down on the sugar by almost half because I was serving it to a diabetic. I elimated the poppy seeds because another of my guests has diverticulitis. text:
It was very good but too sweet, so next time I made it I used the base idea and got a little creative.  I added a bag of shredded red cabbage along with the bag of cole slaw, 2 heaping TBS dried minced onion, mayo, 1/4 cup Splenda, 2 TBS cider vinegar, 1/4 tsp celery seed and a sprinkling of caraway seed.  This was more to our taste. Loved it and will make it again "my way".  Thanks Sandi for a nice base recipe

text:
This is great as is, but sweet. I use 1/3 cup Miracle whip + 1/3 cup Mayo, only 2 T. vegetable oil and only 1/3 c. sugar. We serve it on buttered grilled buns with the Slow Cooker Texas Pulled Pork recipe from this site. DIVINE COMBO!!! Sometimes I'll add an additional 1/2 bag (6 oz.) of Broccoli Slaw, and there's plenty of dressing to coat.

None
text:
This is my third or fourth time using this recipe and I love it! However this is my very 1st time making this slaw since going egg free and it was still delicious even with substitutions. Instead of salad dressing or mayo I used Veganaise (basically vegan mayo), 1/4 cup  fine granulated organic sugar instead of white, and last but not least I didn't have any vegetable oil so I used olive oil instead. I know, I know you can't switch up ingredients and leave a review but I've made this recipe following it to a T as well and was actually compelled to join allrecipes just to comment because it still tasted delicious EVEN with my substitutions. Lol. Yeah, I know most people would think you can't mess up coleslaw but I've been to enough cookouts to know that you CAN. Lol. Make this recipe with or without minor substitutions it will most likely still be delish! Thanks for the recipe Sandy!

Others said that it is a tad bit on the sweet side...well it is at first, but if you let it sit for a good 3 hours in the fridge, the flavors come together and it is FABULOUS! None
text:
Super good slaw recipe. If you read the recipe carefully, you can see that by adding Miracle Whip AND sugar that this will be super sweet. I like a sweet coleslaw but opted to use Best Foods mayo rather than Miracle Whip. It was still very sweet. Also left out the poppy seeds. I doubled the recipe and shredded a whole head of cabbage plus carrots. My entire family (including kids) loved this. I like to leave mine in the refrigerator over night rather than just a couple of hours. It absolutely needs to sit for AT LEAST a couple of hours. It really does taste just like KFC's coleslaw and it's quite tasty. This is my new recipe for coleslaw - goes great on top of pulled pork or corned beef sandwiches!

text:
I made this recipe because of the rave reviews. I've just eaten it and it's overpoweringly sweet. I can only think that maybe restaurant coleslaws over here are not as sweet as in American restaurants. I did expect a sweet coleslaw, but just not one as sweet as this. I tried the dressing before I mixed it in with the salad and it was so sweet it I would almost have been able to use it as a dessert sauce. I decided to add half the quantity of all the other ingredients again to try and temper the sugar and used that, but it was still too sweet for both my partner and me. I will try the recipe again and use much less sugar as so many other reviewers have done, then I am sure, it will be a five star for me as I did like the consistency of the dressing very much. I am so very sorry though, because as the recipe stands, it was not for us at all.

This was SOOOO DELICIOUS! I was making it for a large gathering so I used 3 bags of coleslaw and only doubled the sauce....there was plenty. Also after making it a few times, I highly recommend using mayo over miracle whip (way too sweet w whip), and celery seeds over the poppy. Everything else is just to your taste. I used half the oil called for and used olive oil, an extra splash of vinegar, and fresh cracked pepper. Absolutley amazing...my mother-in-law said it was the best she had ever had!

text:
I had half a head of cabbage in the fridge that I wanted to use up, so I decided to make this slaw. To the shredded cabbage, I added 2 big handfuls of shredded carrot (I had a bag of pre-shredded in the fridge). I also upped the onion to 4 tablespoons. I made the dressing exactly as directed, except I subbed celery seeds for the poppy seeds, and added plenty of freshly cracked black pepper. It is absolutely delicious, and definitely as good, if not better, than what you would get in a restaurant! Sweet, crunchy, and creamy....YUM!! :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! Reliable good taste.  As other reviewers suggested, I reduced the sugar to just under 1/3 cup, which is still slightly too sweet. This might have something to do with using Miracle Whip instead of mayo. Miracle Whip is definitely sweeter than mayonnaise. I also substituted celery seeds for poppy seeds due to allergies and because I like the taste of the celery seeds.  As a twist, I have also added about a tablespoon of horseradish for some zing. I have also used white wine vinegar instead of plain white vinegar for a slightly different taste. For another different taste,  I added shredded lettuce and blue cheese crumbles just before serving. Yummy if you like blue cheese. Great slaw.

text:
I made this cole slaw for my fiance who is very picky about his "slaw".  I've watched him try many different types of cole slaw in varying restaurants, etc. only to see his disappointment.  He loved this cole slaw and now I'll be making this over and over!  No restaurant recipe will ever match this one in his opinion...I liked it too!  The only changes I made (per other reviewers), I used 1/2 rice wine vinegar and 1/2 white vinegar,  reduced the sugar to 1/3 cup, and added 1/4 tsp. of celery seed for additional flavor.

Great coleslaw in a hurry! I made it per the recipe the first time, found it a little sweet but otherwise very good. text:
Most excellent; love this coleslaw! I added half an 8 oz bag of red cabbage, chopped a bit, plus four radishes, diced.  I've made this twice and find that it only needs 1/2 cup of mayo and 1/3 cup sugar for my tastes. I subbed 2 tbsp of rice vinegar for white.  Plenty of dressing for me. No onions or poppy seeds; might try that some day, but for now I am very happy with this method.  I did add fresh ground black pepper pepper at all stages, including the dressing. Will certainly make this again!  Thank you!

Five stars because it is so simple to make!  I made a few modifications.  I cut the sugar to 1/3 cup, 1/2 is too sweet if you plan to use miracle whip.  I cut the salt to 1/8 tsp due to my sodium intake restrictions.  I did not add the poppy seed because I didn't have any.  Next time, I will try using mayo instead of miracle whip.  I also thought about adding crushed pineapple!  Yum!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been the best coleslaw and a favorite at our house. I made this last summer when I was feeding 100 people. I even had people who don't like coleslaw say they liked it. I like it with Best Foods Mayonnaise. I used an off brand once and bad mistake. I don't think I would like it with Miricle Whip. Even my family who are Miracle Whip fans say it's best with Mayo. I don't use the bag of coleslaw mix. I use a small or half a large head of cabbage shredded very fine and chopped and 1 carrot grated. Make sure you give it time to blend flavors. People say they like it because it's not too heavy with sauce. It's a nice mix.

text:
This was very tasty!  So much better than all the bottled dressings I've tried and very easy to mix up!  I did have to cut back on the sugar, though.  A half cup seemed like too much so I only used 1/4 cup and it was plenty sweet.  Also this makes a lot of dressing!  For our family's taste it was too much dressing for just one bag of coleslaw so next time I will either half the dressing recipe or use two bags of coleslaw.

text:
I just made this to go with tonight's dinner of Irish Tacos off this site. For some reason I was thinking this recipe called for 1 pound (wowie!) of coleslaw, and we had a 14 ounce bag, so I pretty much halved everything except the mayo and added WAY more onion (A whole medium one) I'm glad I thought that, because with the 1/4 cup sugar, it was pretty sweet. I couldn't imagine it with 1/2 cup! I used rice wine vinegar instead, and olive oil. Tastes pretty good, and I can't wait to have it on my corned beef tavos tonight!

text:
My family loved this!  I used 1/3 cup white sugar because I use Miracle Whip and it has a sweeter taste (to me, at least) than mayonnaise.  It was perfect.  I mixed the dressing ingredients up the day before and put the onion in with the dressing.  The next morning I poured the dressing on the cabbage, covered the bowl, and put it in the refrigerator.  I stirred once or twice before dinner.  Couldn't be easier or more tasty!

text:
Overall, this slaw is good. It is sweet, even after following the advice of the other reviewers, and reducing the sugar (I doubled the recipe, and used 2/3 of a cup of sugar, instead of the 1 1/3 cups the recipe called for).I doctored the recipe with extra vinegar, to counter the sweetness. I also reduced the oil by 1 tablespoon, eliminated the dill seed and used regular mayo. I added some black pepper as well. So far, it tastes pretty good. The onion definitely gives it a nice flavor, Next time, I'll try adding the dill seed.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only gave this 3 stars because of all the changes I made to the original recipe. I definitely suggest using this recipe as a base, and making changes to your own taste. The first time I made it I followed the recipe exactly, but it's way too sweet if you use the amount of sugar as written.  So...using other reviewer suggestions...here's how I made it the second time and it came out really good!  I cut the sugar in half, doubled the amount of vinegar (because it tasted too much like Miracle Whip the first time) and substituted celery seed for the poppy seed.  I also chopped a head of cabbage and bought matchstick carrots and chopped those too (if you have the time it's better than bagged).  I also added salt and pepper to taste at the end.  Very tasty!

I really liked this recipe.  One thing that I would change is the amount of sugar.  I like EVERYTHING sweet, but this was way too much sugar even for me. Otherwise, I really liked this recipe.  Like I said, I like everything sweet so this was a hit for me with the sugar adjustment.

This is a relatively familiar recipe for me but still remains a favourite for everyone I prepare it for. I also scale back the sugar a tad,  sub the oil for a couple dollops of sour cream, white vinegar for white wine vinegar, add a Tbsp of Dijon mustard and the juice from 1/2 lemon and a few shakes of Franks (I did say relatively familiar...lol). I think the moral of the story is that using the staple ingredients is key, but mess with 'em as you like. Thanks for the recipe Sandi!

I have made this recipe over and over. I've served it to sooo many people and everyone loves it!  I did change a couple things just to cut down a bit on the sweetness and fat. text:
Eagerly, I sat down at my computer to pull this recipe up. I had made it a week or so ago and after serving it at dinner to my Mom and Dad, Mom brought me a head of cabbage so I would make some up for them. With horror, I realized I had not saved it to my recipe box! Nearly had a heart attack trying to find it! When I did find it the first thing I did was click the "add to recipe box" tab and only THEN could I breathe with relief! Whew! It is wonderful! The only changes I made personally was to use a whole onion per bag of slaw mix rather than the 2 tablespoons called for...(in this family you can't get enough onion) and I used celery seed instead of poppy seed. 
My nephew declared it wasn't "LIKE" KFC, it WAS KFC slaw! My only slaw recipe from now on...making it for a friends b-day party where I will no doubt have a few recipe cards with this recipe on it to hand out to everyone that wants it....this is your recipe folks!

text:
I've been using a recipe from my husband's family that was passed down for over a century.  This was a lot easier with less ingredients, and no one seemed to notice the change.  Great taste!  If you have a food processor, make your own coleslaw by cutting up the cabbage, shredding carrots, and by chopping up a small green pepper, celery, and onion.  You'll get a lot more coleslaw for a lower price.  I also made a homemade version of Miracle Whip for this.

text:
This was my first venture with making cole slaw.  I would have to say that it was even better than restaurant slaw.  DEFINITELY better than deli counter slaw!!!! Yum yum!!  Made it just as written except for using mayo in place of Miracle Whip (personal preference). As posted, it does get more watery as it sits (no fault of the recipe, just the nature of cabbage). The taste just gets better and better as it sits and its super simple to drain off excess fluids if desired.  Unquestionably a keeper!!  ***** UPDATE: Just made it again but this time, used Broccoli Slaw (found same place as shredded cole slaw in store). did taste different than original but still very, very good. And healthier!!  Either version is a winner!!!!

text:
This was good and easy!  Trying to reduce carbs, I made it with the Splenda that measures like sugar.  The packaged slaw was 3 net carbs per 1 cup serving, 5 carbs minus 2 g fiber. I used real mayo, 1 Tbsp onion (because the onion was strong) and less oil because I prefer slaw that is not too liquidy.  Vinegar varies, using white vinegar adds the perfect tartness.  Looking forward to using this on turkey or corned beef low carb wraps! Thanks for posting!

very good for pulled pork sandwiches. I cut up my own mix instead of using bagged. Cabbage cut into small strips and carrots, onion, and apples grated thinly. During the summer, I often add a few fresh, garden radishes. Thanks for the great recipe!

I don't eat cole slaw, but my husband and mother does, and they said that this was as close as you can get to what you can order from any restaurant. I have made it twice within a week. The first time, I made it with everything but the poppy seeds because I didn't have any. The second time I made it, I included the poppy seeds, used finely diced celery in place of onions, and added 2 tsp of half and half, since my husband likes it more wet. He said that it was exactly like he remembered the way his grandfather made it who was a cook in the navy. 
Thank you for a recipe that I will be making for years to come.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
No surprise, everyone at the event loved this slaw, even a few "i love the slaw...and i don't usually like cole slaw!"  Of course it was meant to accompany my pulled pork sliders, which this slaw is seriously the PERFECT accompaniment to pulled pork.  My variation: 2T diced onion (from the spices aisle, i didn't bother dicing an onion!,) 1/2 c. LIGHT mayo,  2T vinegar, and 1/4 c. + 2 T sugar...plus i used celery seeds instead of poppy seeds, and I doubled what the recipe called for.  Plus some fresh cracked black pepper... the recipe sounded too sweet for my liking and i wanted something a little tangier, thus cutting out some sugar and adding in more vinegar (if you want just add to taste.)  turned out great...now i have a keeper for cole slaw!

Pretty darn good!  I used canaola mayo and substituted good local honey for the sugar (1-3/4 tbl but I would put about 2 to 2-1/4 tbs next time), I added a little over 1/4 tsp dry mustard, few shakes of pepper a little more salt.  I used olive oil instead of canola.  I will probably add some radishes as others have done.  Very good slaw.  I will use it again.

text:
I read some of the comments about it being too sweet and since I try to steer clear of pesticide ridden food, I used organic broccoli shred mix from Trader Joes.  The broccoli really balanced out some of the excess sweetness previously referred to.  Since the bag of broccoli shreds is smaller than 16 ounces, I supplemented it with additional shredded carrots.  This is by far the best coleslaw dressing recipe I have made - sorry Grandma but this recipe has topped our secret family recipe!

region:

country:
None
text:
Delicious, with the amount of sugar cut in half, as other reviewers suggested. Also, I use real mayonnaise (Dukes) instead of Miracle Whip, and cider vinegar (doubled to 2 tablespoons). Everyone I've served slaw to, dressed using this recipe, loves it. Most say it's the best slaw they've ever had. Also, the dressing keeps really well, so I make up double batches and store it in the fridge for whenever we need it. Another thing that's good is to sub celery seed for the poppy seeds, or use a mix of both. I found this recipe a few years ago, and haven't bought slaw dressing since.

country:

text:
Word is in!  According to my family, this is THE best coleslaw ever!  After reading reviews, I knew I wanted to stick to the basic recipe and give it a shot.  In the end, I only made a couple minor changes so it would be more like KFC's (which my family loves).  I chopped my bag of 16oz. coleslaw mix into smaller chunks like KFC.  I added one shredded carrot because my mix was a little lite on the carrots.  Inadvertantely used only 2T of vegetable oil - and it was fine - and used celery seed instead of poppy because that's what I had and it seems to fit better.  I also used a tablespoon of Apple Cider Vinegar in addition to the regular.  According to my family, this coleslaw is "the bomb dot com" so I had to taste it - and it's the first time I ever really liked Coleslaw.  It's a bit sweet for my taste, but the family says it's supposed to be.  Thank you so much for posting this family favorite recipe!!!

None
text:
I made the dressing exactly as directed in the recipe,  I did use cabbage and carrots I grew in my garden instead of using the mix from the store.  I'm not a miracle whip kinda girl, always prefer mayo, but a personal rule is to always make a new recipe the way the author directs before making any changes.  I'm glad I used the miracle whip, it added a nice mellow tang.  This was the sweetest, freshest tasting coleslaw I have ever tasted.  Everyone absolutely loved it.  The dressing was great, not too sweet for me.  It was a little runny, but I think that is from the natural juices of the cabbage - the juices did not deter from the yummy-ness, just needed a slotted spoon.  I'm thinking of doubling my cabbage crop next year just so I can enjoy more of this wonderful coleslaw.  I'm sure it will be hit with the store bought coleslaw mix, too.  I will definately make this recipe again.  Thanks Sandi!

This recipe is really sweet! I guess I should have believed the title when I read it. It has to be modified to reduce the sugar to appeal to more people. I have made it 3 times to try to get the sugar balance right. On my last try I think I may have come really close. I used regular mayo instead of salad dressing, because it has no added sugar to it. I added about 1/4 tsp more vinegar and cut the sugar in half to 1/4 cup. I may even cut the sugar back a tad more next time. As is I can't say I have ever had coleslaw this sweet anywhere? And, I really like coleslaw. When the ingredients are mixed the dressing will settle to the bottom some, but the coleslaw actually tastes pretty good then.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty and easy to make.  I made a few adjustments which I would highly recommend: used good mayo instead of Miracle Whip, and added a bit of extra vinegar so the mix was not as thick.  I also cut real cabbage after eyeing the wilty looking pre-cut coleslaw mixes at the grocery store.  As a result, our coleslaw was really crunchy and lasted a few days for leftovers.  I'd also recommend letting it marinate longer than the recommended two hours - ours marinated for four and I think it could have used another two hours (next time I'll try six hours). We served this with brisket and cornbread - delish!

text:
This was a good recipe, and my first time making cole slaw.  I followed recipe exactly except that I cut sugar down because it seemed like it would be too sweet.  I could not find bagged cole slaw mix, so I bought a head of cabbage and shredded it myself, along with carrots.  I used celery seed instead of poppy seeds because of others suggestions.  Mixed it all together and let it sit overnight.  Tasted it in the morning and it was still pretty bitter, the fresh cabbage had a distinctive taste!  So I added the rest of the sugar that I left out previously and it was great.  Next time I will shred my cabbage a little finer because my only complaint was that the pieces were too big.  Word to other chefs:  Make recipe as called for and it will be wonderful!

text:
I have never been a fan of Coleslaw, but my other half loves it, so after 34 years of marriage, I decided to try making it for him on his birthday. I bought the BIG bag of mix, and calculated I'd need to quadruple the recipe! The amount of Miracle Whip and sugar was a little shocking, but hubby LOVED the slaw; best he'd ever had, apparently! Served it with Shepherd's pie. Everyone enjoyed, and had seconds- even me! he was finishing it off two days later. A little soupy by then, but still delicious! No point messing with the recipe. It might not be the Weight watchers choice, but it's a tasty option. I imagine it would be fantastic with pulled pork!

I've made this many times at BBQs to go along with pulled pork, etc. It is delicious and always GONE very quickly. It is heavy on the dressing - so I either add more cabbage or don't add as much dressing, etc. Whatever the case may be, I marinate it in the dressing at least 12 hours before serving so the flavors have time to really combine. AMAZING!

text:
I had to tweak this recipe a bit, but only because I do not like a lot of the miracle whip on my coleslaw.  I do not like to cover the flavor of the cabbage.  I also added a 1/2 a teaspoon of pepper, and 1/2 a tablespoon of minced garlic, and 1/4 teaspoon mustard with horseradish.  This recipe is great how it is, but for my family this is how we prefer it.  Thank you for sharing this wonderful recipe, I have never been able to eat and like coleslaw until this, original, recipe.

text:
I did like this recipe and I would have given it 5 stars if I hadn't read the other reviews and reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup instead of the 1/2 cup the original calls for. I didn't think it was sweet enough with only half the amount of sugar. It was a little on the tangy side, which was good, but I think it would have been better with a half cup of sugar to offset the tangy-ness. And I didn't think it was goopy at all. Next time I make it, I will use the recipe as is and it should be a 5-star rating. :)

This is great with the rootbeer pulled pork that is on this site that is cooked in the slow cooker!!!

userID:
11310917
Display Name:
wmorales
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been looking for the perfect cole slaw recipe and this is it!  Easy to make and taste even better a few days after.  I made the dressing the day before I was ready to use it and I only took out  the amount of salad I need it and put it together 20 minutes before use. It was nice and crisp. I think that if everything is mixed for a long period of time it will get soggy. Like other reviews I used mayo since I don't buy miracle whip.  Anyone that wants to try it, should.  Not sure if next time I will reduce the sugar to one third. The half cup did not bother me since me and my husband like sweet things. I also added a purple onion at the end before serving it. I did not used poppy seeds because I did not had them on hand. The best review on my side, my husband thought I bought it!!
Review:
Rating:
1

text:
Whenever I make this, everybody comments on how much it tastes like (dare I say it) Kentucky Fried Chicken coleslaw.  I do reduce the sugar just a little bit, even though I like sweet things, this didn't need that much sugar.  It's surprising how when you initially mix the dressing with the cabbage, it looks like there is NO WHERE NEAR enough dressing...but don't let that fool you.  You must let it chill in the refrigerator for a few hours, and the cabbage softens up, resulting in a nice, crunchy and juicy salad.

The two changes I made was I used 1/3 cup Miracle Whip and 1/3 cup mayo - my sister likes one and I prefer the other so we compromised; and I cut the sugar by half. Because of these changes I can't rate the original recipe but with my changes I liked this a lot and will add it to my recipe box.

text:
Leave out the poppy seeds - they aren't that pretty, and no one cares what this cole slaw looks like, because it's devoured so quickly!  This slaw is sweet, yet tangy (add extra vinegar or onion to up the "tang" factor).  I've yet to find anyone that doesn't like this recipe. It tastes like a better version of KFC.  This has quickly become my go-to  recipe for an easy, crowd-pleasing potluck/picnic/etc. dish.

country:
None
text:
great recipe! it got devoured at our housewarming pot-luck i made this for. i followed instructions and chilled it for at least two hours before serving, which did make a big difference. but i was a little unimpressed with how runny it became after a bit. i ended up having to drain it some so it still looked appealing and had to stir it often. one suggestion i will make is to omit using miracle whip (being as how that has a more "sweet" taste) and use regular mayo- with the amount of sugar the recipe calls for, miracle whip would have been too much on the "sweet" side. i think the sugar could still be cut down just a bit. and i also did not use poppy seeds. i have never had a slaw with poppy seeds and saw no use or appeal for them. maybe i did something wrong with mine being runny, but otherwise, this is an excellent recipe and i will make it again.

this is absolutely delicious!!! i didnt have the ready coleslaw mix so i used half a baby cabbage and one carrot which i washed and since i dont have a salad spinner, i put it in a clean pillow case, spun it outside until all the water was out and hung it on the washing line to dry for a few minutes. i did not want any water water messing up the end result! i did use slighlty less sugar than the recipe called for and a little more salt.i also added a pinch of white pepper. it was a huge hit!

WOW! I used a half a head of cabbage and about 8 baby carrots... threw into food proccessor until minced.. ( I promise, this makes THE BEST coleslaw consistency EVER, Lee's Famous Recipe was always the only kind I have ever eaten!) ... I just eyeballed the mayo (used Hellmans), and used some sour cream (no oil), celery salt, salt, pepper, 3 capfuls of apple cider vinegar, and 1/3 cup sugar. This is the best coleslaw EVER! I will usually only eat it from Lee's Famous Recipe! From now on, I will be making my own!!! YUM! 4 stars for adjustments, but they were according to my preferences. If you are partial to Lee's, try my suggestions! You will be over the moon! ; D

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2012-07-05T18:19:07.023
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
6964007
Display Name:
ekc
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
6
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My 1st time making cole slaw. 1) I shredded my own veggies. 1 head cabbage, about 1/3 head red cabbage, 2 carrots. Cut cabbage with a knife. Shredded carrots w/a Benriner. Ended up with a lot of veggies (overflowing my large mixing bowl), so I doubled the sauce recipe. 2) It was honestly pretty gross seeing all the gloppy fatty goop that goes into the mixture. Next time I will try not doubling the sauce, and/or may try cutting out the oil, as one reviewer suggested. 3) Just after mixing it together, it tasted extremely sugary sweet. So I added another Tbsp of vinegar, another Tbsp of diced onion (leftover from my cutting board), and several dashes of salt. 4) After sitting for 2hrs in the fridge, liquid mixture/sauce had formed, so before serving, I drained that excess liquid and somewhat squeezed the slaw before putting into a serving bowl. About 1 hr later, the slaw was pooling again, so I think draining is a good thing. 5) The cole slaw was actually delicious. I mean, really really good! 6) Had the leftover slaw today. More liquid mixture formed so put the slaw in a colander and let it drain into a large bowl before eating. I figured it helped cut down on the fat and calories. Loved it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband went NUTS over this. He prefers mayo based slaws, but certainly didn't complain that I'd balanced out the sweetness with vinegar. Instead of coleslaw mix, I sliced up a fresh head of Savoy cabbage (if you've never tried Savoy, treat yourself). I also chose to add 1/2 cup each blueberries and golden raisins to add color and texture. After reading reviews, sauce consisted of 1 cup mayo, 2/3 cup sugar, 2 1/2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar, 1 teaspoon kosher salt and 3 tablespoons vegetable oil. Sliced onions on mandoline using thinnest setting, also sliced cabbage on mandoline. Never have poppy seeds, but always have celery seed. This was amazing. Lovely creamy sauce, ate slaw right after preparation and it was fantastic. We're looking forward to leftovers tonight.

text:
I made this recipe with a few changes. According to other reviewers, it was too sweet so I used 1/3 cup of sugar. I also cut the vegetable oil to 2-1/2 tablespoons instead of 3. I didn't add the poppy seeds and the only vinegar I had was white wine vinegar, so I used that. I didn't have much time to let it settle in the fridge for 2 hours so I put it in the freezer for about 30 minutes or so.. it seems to speed that process up a bit and it tasted pretty good. I'm not normally a fan of coleslaw but I think I'm starting to like it!

text:
I generally prefer to make my own cole slaw from scratch including shredding the carrots, and cabbage myself. I like it to be cut fine. However, this recipe is a huge timesaver when you buy the bag of coleslaw mix at the store. I agree that the dressing is a little too sweet but I enjoyed it anyway. I used Miracle Whip and had just enough in my refrigerator for this recipe.  I think this recipe is excellent, especially if you're in a hurry. And I love that it does not require any unusual ingredients. Thank you, Sandi! (I did not add the poppy seeds because mine had been in the cupboard forever and I was afraid they would taste bad).

None
text:
So yummy! I followed this recipe as directed except used real mayo instead of Miracle Whip, and omitted the poppy seeds. Wow! It was absolutely delicious and so easy! After reading other reviews I had concerns it may be too sweet, but it wasn't at all. I suspect switching to regular mayo made it slightly more tart than Miracle Whip would have, and that is exactly what I was going for. I'm not sure from where, but it tasted 'familiar' to me. I let it sit in the fridge for a couple of hours before serving. While it did have a lot of watery dressing underneath it, it remained crisp, light, and crunchy. I simply used a slotted spoon while serving to release excess dressing. I will be making this again, and I will not change a thing!

I made this with 1/2 head of small cabbage (20 oz.) and 3 carrots, which I shredded in the food processor. I then used the food processor to make the dressing.  There was more than enough, despite initially looking a bit dry.

     I used mayo instead of Miracle Whip and celery seed instead of poppy seed, because I didn't have either.  I also reduced the sugar to 1/3 c. which was plenty of sweetness.  With these minor changes, only because I had to, this was excellent.  I will make this again!

text:
Very good as is. I too use celery seed instead of poppy seed but sparingly as it can overpower the slaw. Mayo is my choice as it gives a more of an egg flavor over salad dressing. Another slight change I make occasionally is to use a diced firm apple in place of some of the sugar. Glad to see that you didn't kill it with horseradish. Too many recipes wreck the slaw with too much of it.

region:

country:
None
text:
I stopped eating at that chicken place with 3 letters in the name, after seeing how they mishandle their poultry, and getting sick atleast twice from it. But, I grew up on the stuff and I judge all coleslaw on the way they make it. I really miss the stuff!
Two things that I have to mention, the white onion definately adds that flavor that other slaws don't seem to have. I never would have put my finger on it, but it really makes the flavor what it is. 2nd, I have made this several times and chop the cabbage fine (only fresh, never bagged) and I can't stop the cabbage from releasing liquid and making this slaw really wet. Drain and repeat, and still wet. I may try keeping the cabbage shaved instead of fine. I have yet to find the perfect sweetness but overall the recipe is there. Goodjob on this one, it'll just take a few attempts to perfect.

text:
Awesome cole slaw recipe!  I was so proud of myself after having made it.  Who knew that cole slaw was so easy to make?! I did cut back a bit on the sugar as other reviewers suggested - I used 1/3c. and I also added just a couple drops more of the vinegar for extra tanginess and omitted the poppy seeds.  I also used light Miracle Whip.  I was concerned if the light would make a big difference, and it didn't.  Will definitely be making this recipe again!

text:
Incredible! My kids love slaw. No matter where it comes from, they will eat it. I was a cashier at the chicken place when I was in high school and the cashiers were responsible for making the slaw, among other things. 50 pounds of cabbage plus a ratio of onions and carrots that I have since forgotten.  Just a few of the outside leaves. Not too many though because that would make it more bitter.  But the dark green leaves was to make it look pretty. LOL  After the cabbage, slaw and onions went through the machine with the huge rotating blade.  After all had gone through, we poured in a gallon (or two) of the dressing that was purchased already premade.

I did like I knew and chopped the cabbage and onions by hand and sent the carrot through my salad shooter (cabbage is too wet to survive in the size that I want) and it took me back many years.  And then . . . THIS dressing looked exactly like the dressing I remember.  And after I poured it into the cabbage mixture, I KNEW I had that slaw from long ago.  Now theirs is dry and this is the moist slaw that I remember.  INCREDIBLE!!

My 6yo told me that if it tasted like the Captain fish's place, he was going to eat it all up and ask for more and more and more.  When he tasted it, he told me that it WAS better than that.  He got seconds and thirds.  My 11yo daughter kept getting spoonfuls. And the 4yo gobbled his up. They couldn't get enough.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My absolute favorite coleslaw recipe! I always get a ton of complements every time I make it. My boyfriends mother requests it for every family BBQ and keeps whatever's leftover for herself! Some suggestions I have after playing around with the recipe a bit: Only use 1/4 a cup of sugar, use real mayo instead of Miracle Whip (not a mayo vs Miracle Whip preference thing, I actually HATE mayo on my sandwiches, etc. but it just works better with coleslaw IMO!) add a little red wine vinegar (or just some red wine if you don't have red wine vinegar on hand) in addition to the white vinegar (no specific measurement, I usually just wing it. ) and chop up some green onion for extra flavor. Chill in the fridge for at least an hour and wella! Best recipe ever!

I joined just so I could save THIS recipe. SO good! I used real mayo instead of the miracle whip and added a splash of rice vinegar (in addition to the white vinegar the recipe calls for).

text:
I think if you use Miracle Whip, which already is a sweet mayonnaise, the recipe will definitely come out too sweet. I like my Cole Slaw a little sweet but this was too sweet. I had to add another  teaspoon of salt and about 1 tablespoon of lemon juice to make it enjoyable. Next time I make this recipe I will probably cut the sugar in half and use regular mayonnaise.

WOW!  So easy and so good!  I doubled the recipe, used regular mayo, and added an additional Tbsp of vinegar and it was GREAT.  I'd recommend chilling this for at least 4 hours, so the cabbage gets soft enough and the flavors blend.  I tried another "restaurant style" coleslaw recipe from this site, and this one far exceeded it.  YUM!

text:
I dont like to rate a recipe when I didnt follow it exactly but I cant not rate this! Just because I hope someone with my taste takes the time to read the reviews and stumbles upon mine. And I know people with a taste opposite of mine love this recipe as it is written. All I did was substitute mayonaise for the miracle whip. And it was really sweet but a tad not tangy enough for my taste. Also I didnt have bagged coleslaw mix so I used half a cabbage and shredded a big carrot, and used a bit more onion because hubby loves it. This was just delicious the way I made it! Actually reminds me more of the salad dressing they use at teriyaki joints. I always have loved that dressing but couldn't find it anywhere for a long time.  This wasn't tangy enough to taste to me like coleslaw usually does. None the less, I love this so much! And I made this last minute while waiting for ribs to be done and refrigirated the coleslaw for about 5 minutes and it was great! The sugar melted and some liquid came out. Amazing! And I dont say that unless it is absolutely great. Try it! If you like sweet, sub mayo for the miracle whip, if you like it super super sweet, follow the recipe to the T.

text:
I read the comments about this recipe being a bit too sweet. However, I like to make the original recipe first. It was so sweet I chucked it and started over using a quarter of the sugar. Half the sugar that this recipe calls for does the trick; that is if you like it a bit sweet. If not, use even less sugar and add to taste. After remaking it using only a quarter of the sugar and a fresh coleslaw mix instead of store bought, it was excellent. However, if you like nearly half a spoon full of sugar in every bite stick to the original recipe.

text:
Great cole slaw!  I had a very firm cabbage that I shredded then added a large shredded carrot instead of the bagged stuff.  I think I had more cabbage than is in the bag, but that was OK because we don't like goopy slaw.  I used light Miracle Whip and Splenda.  I also increased the vinegar to 3 T.  It was a little bit sweet for me but my husband said it was the best he's ever eaten.  This is my new cole slaw recipe!

text:
OMG - YUM!  This is JUST like Kentucky Fried Chicken coleslaw.  I will never buy coleslaw from our grocery store deli again - because this recipe is SIMPLE to make and phenomenal in taste!  The ONLY modifications I made is to the split the 2/3 C. of creamy salad dressing with half Mayo and half Salad Dressing (Miracle Whip), and added 1/2 tsp. of celery seed, in addition to the poppy seed it called for.  Oh, also I only used 1/4 C. of sugar - figured I could add more later - but I didn't need too - 1/4 C. was MORE than enough. Just right!!!  Unless you like super sweet cole slaw, I recommend cutting down the sugar!  Well worth time/effort and great for any occassion!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This is just "perfect" slaw -- sweet and creamy with a little tang.  I wilted the slaw mix first so I didn't have a puddle in the bottom of the bowl.  To wilt, place slaw in colander, and mix with 2 tsp salt.  Let stand 2-4 hours until it releases most of its water.  It will look horrible -- almost like cooked cabbage.  Rinse well, spin, and pat dry.  Continue with recipe as written.

Display Name:
Alex Aviance

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2994214.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this all the time and have been for years. It's the only slaw recipe I need. It's awesome for pulled pork sandwiches and goes great with any BBQ.

Having made this dozens of times I can safely say a few things: 

The sugar should be adjusted for your own tastes and I feel like it makes way too much dressing for 1 bag of coleslaw so I always cut back the ingredients or add more slaw. 

Also after sitting in the fridge for a few hours it will accumulate a fair amount of water at the bottom of the container. This isn't a problem with the dressing being runny, but the salt in the ingredients pulling the water out of the cabbage. I always mix it up with the liquid and discreetly pour out the excess before serving or it's just going to be super runny when someone puts it on their plate.

5

text:
I am a little bit of a coleslaw snob but I am always looking for something different or new. This is by far my favorite slaw recipe. I used apple cider vinegar instead of white and added 2 extra tablespoons. I also used extra virgin olive oil instead of regular vegetable oil. I like onion so I doubled the onion. Instead poppy seeds I used dill. I also added 2 tablespoons of lemon juice which I always do to my slaw recipes. It cuts the sweetness a little and made it just perfect for us. This is a recipe I will use from now on.

text:
I love cole slaw, but have never made it. My issue with store bought is that, while I love the taste of several, I usually avoid the sugar that they add. So I made this recipe with Splenda instead of white sugar. Also I don't have any poppy seeds. Tried it right after I made it and thought "good". Then left it in fridge for a couple hours. It softened and dropped about 50 percent of it's volume. Tasted it and proceeded to eat the whole batch. Easy and super good, Splenda worked great.

country:
None
text:
Great basic, but try adding a carrot or two for color and substitute the poppy seeds for celery seeds to add extra flavor (but if you do use only a quarter of the amount).

Instead of Miracle Whip, I used real mayo and added dashes of cayenne pepper and black pepper, and I omitted the oil.

Also, making it with half sugar, half granular Splenda doesn't hurt the flavor a bit.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-09-03T11:58:07.25
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1335526
Display Name:
KAYLYN2
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
62
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I haven't taken the time rate or review a recipe in a long time; however, this recipe is worth reviewing.  It is seriously amazing!  Earlier this summer, I had to prepare a few meals for a group of 300+.  This was by far one of the items everyone ranted and raved about.  I didn't change a thing, (although the dressing goes a long way.  So if you are making a large amount of coleslaw, I recommend only adding some of it, mixing it with the cabbage, and then adding more as needed.)  I also suggest adding more actually coleslaw mix to the dressing.  Once the dressing is poured on, the coleslaw mix shrinks down quite a bit.  The dressing itself is perfect!  The only thing I have ever left out is the poppy seeds, simply because I forgot to buy them.  It was delicious just the same.  I have used the slaw on barbecue pulled pork sandwiches (like at Cafe Zupa's.)  I have also used it just as a side.  The only tip I would give is that when I serve it just as a side, I love to have bacon cooked and chopped, as well as peanuts chopped (if no one is allergic), and set on the side for people to top their slaw with if they want.  Divine!  Thank you so much for this recipe!!!!

text:
I used the 16 oz bag but used celery seed instead of poppy seeds.
Basically when I put this together it tasted just like miracle whip. It did not taste like slaw. That was yucky. I had to add  bunch more vinegar and oil and then a little more sugar. Then it tasted like slaw should. It got juicier over night. The miracle whip is way too much for this recipe. As for sugar how much you want will vary per person and needs to be adjusted when cooking or preparing. I like mine sweet. Ill rate it as OK because it seemed to work for so many people and it was great after I diluted the salad dressing with vinegar and oil.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am on a diet and can't eat store bought coleslaw anymore.  So I started looking for one I could easily convert to a lower calorie version and found this one.  I simply substituted Miracle Whip lite for regular, granulated Splenda for sugar, and 2 Tbs of sour cream and 2 Tbs of vinegar for the oil and vinegar combination above.  By my rough calculations it cut calories from 1250 calories for the entire batch down to about 380 calories for my light version!  It still tasted great, better than 50-75% of restaurant store bought full calorie kind.  The only change is I may try to knock out a little of the Miracle Whip as there is a lot of coating on mine because I didn't check until later but my cole slaw mix was only 14 ounces.

None
text:
Okay...yum.  I rarely rate recipes, and to do so now for, of all things, cole slaw?  Mostly, cole slaw is just there, like a dish of white rice, or a bowl of oatmeal.  But THIS cole slaw was really, really good.  I sliced my own cabbage, and found that doubling the dressing recipe was the perfect amount for one entire head of cabbage.   Do yourself a favor: halve the sugar then taste it.  You can always add the other half of the sugar if it's not sweet enough for you, but I found that is was perfect with half the sugar, couldn't imagine it any sweeter, and I like it sweet.

Display Name:
frank methmann

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified the recipe as to some of the review suggestions. I used good mayo and omitted the oil, and cut back on the sugar by about 1/4 less of what was called out.I also used the celery seed, as advised in other reviews. I was taking mine to a picnic where there was going to be pulled pork sandwiches, so I added 1 teaspoon of cayenne pepper to kick it up a notch. I assume people will put the slaw on their sandwich. I also should have taken the advice in one of the reviews stating to only add half the sauce at first, then drain off water after about an hour in fridge. I will use a slotted spoon to serve because of the water build up. I also added more shredded carrot and red cabbage to the pre-mix I bought at supermarket. It looked a bit too dry when I first added the ingredients, but I guess the vinegar did it's magic. It cured very nicely. I gave it four stars because of the over sugared original recipe. I think my tweaks came out better.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Let me just say...I don't even like slaw. BUT...so many people do and this was the perfect and easy side for a small gathering I was having. I tasted it and loved it! I prepared the slaw the evening before, so it chilled for a good 17 hours before serving. I found fresh slaw mix at Central Market (not bagged). I used Mayo instead of Miracle Whip since so many reviewers said it was "too sweet". Other than omitting the onions (not a fan of uncooked onions), I followed the recipe as written.  I was shocked when I peeled off the foil to discover the slaw had reduced down to about a third of it's original height! That's probably normal, but having never prepared it, I was not expecting that at all. There were 9 of us (all female), and other than a taste, I didn't serve myself any because I was worried there wouldn't be enough. For that reason, I would say this recipe serves 6 and not 8.  Anyway...I and my non-slaw loving partner REALLY liked this slaw! Not too mayo-y...fresh tasting and perfect flavor for our tastes.  My guests loved it and there was nothing left. I'll be making this easy and tasty recipe again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've used this recipe several times. After the first recipe, I lost the link, so when I found this one, which was close to the original I had used at first, I improvised somewhat by adding 1/8 teaspoon each of garlic powder, and onion salt. Also I doubled the vinegar (2 tablespoons) to balance out the sweetness of the sugar. Onions are another personal choice on measurements. Normally I grate my own cabbage. Not having a scale (next purchase), I put approx., 8 cups of grated cabbage, add the grated carrot, and then add dressing to taste (normally the full recipe). If you want to grate the entire cabbage but not make it all at once, the cabbage will store in a baggie for a few days. Then you can start all over with the dressing.

text:
Miracle Whip is not for the faint of heart. Ergh. I made it with mayo, and what's with the poppy seeds?  Those are celery seed you find in restaurant coleslaw. So that went in instead of the poppy.

Good, very sweet basic recipe.  Tweak it as you like.  Besides the above two changes, I also added yellow mustard [for tang] and brought the sugar down.
 
4 stars for taking the time to share and for the basics. I star off for the use of poppy seed.

I've been making this recipe for awhile now, but I had guests today  that hate sugary salads. I served with pulled pork from this site with some changes:
For one bag of coleslaw I used 1/2 C mayo, 1 tb sour cream, 2 tb sugar, 1 tb rice vinegar, 1/4 ts salt, 1/2 ts poppy seeds and 1/8 ts black pepper.
WONDERFUL!

text:
YUMMY!!!  This is now my go-to salad.  I doubled the recipe and made a few changes.  Here is my version...

2 (16 oz) bags coleslaw mix
1/2 sweet onion, finely diced
2/3 cup mayonnaise
2/3 cup Miracle Whip
4 Tbsp vegetable oil
1 cup sugar
2 Tbsp white wine vinegar
Scant 1/2 tsp salt
1 tsp poppy seeds

text:
This is the best slaw I have ever made, which means it's probably the best slaw I've ever eaten.  I did make a few changes, however.  I used rice vinegar in place of the white vinegar, I reduced the sugar just a bit, though next time I will use the full 1/2 cup.  I also used fresh cabbage, and next time I will add shredded carrots.  Oh, and I used mayo instead of miracle whip, because I am in the camp that believes miracle whip is from the devil.  

Thank you so much for a delicious recipe!  This one will go into my real recipe box.

text:
With over a thousand reviews, this recipe doesn't really need mine, but I can't help myself. It's just that good. This IS my new slaw dressing. This is the first dressing I've ever made or had in a restaurant that held up beyond a day. As a matter of fact, it might have been even better the second day and was still quite edible the third. I suppose it comes from having so little vinegar. Only adjustment I'll make in the future is to add more cabbage. Perhaps my 16 ounces wasn't actually 16 ounces, but it was swimming in a sea of dressing, and I prefer my cabbage to be lightly covered.

text:
This was very good! Only negative was that the dressing seemed sparse when first mixed into the shredded cabbage & carrots but after chilling a few hours became very soupy/runny. It ran all over the plate when dished up, which some people may not like the dressing to mingle with the other food on their plate. I followed to the "T", so don't know if it is suppose to be this way, but too runny for me. That is why I only gave 4 stars. Flavor was great! It is a sweet slaw, so no one should be surprised or rate it low because they think it is too sweet. Personally I loved the flavor! I will make again, I just need to figure out a way to keep the dressing from becoming so runny.

None
text:
I was trying to duplicate the cole slaw from a popular restaurant and I came across this recipe sounding the most like the flavors I was aiming for...
This turned out really good and tangy.
I diced the cabbage and carrots ( that was how the restaurant did it) 
Like the other review I also used rice wine vinegar cuz I had a lot on hand. I used chopped scallions not onions, added garlic powder, and lots black pepper. I used Hellman's lite mayo...I forgot the oil but it really doesn't need  it, so save the extra fat and calories.... It was delicious.

text:
Warning:  Reduce the sugar, otherwise awesome recipe.  I made this recipe for the first time for a Pig Pickin this weekend.  I have never made slaw in my life.  It got rave reviews from the 30+ people in attendance.  I did grate my own cabbage and carrots for the slaw instead of bag slaw.  I quadrupled the recipe (3/4 of a very large head of cabbage and ½ of red cabbage, carrots as preferred) but only used ½ cup of sugar and ¼ cup of oil rather than what was called for in a quadrupled recipe and it was perfect.  I can’t imagine using ½ c sugar in the original recipe when it was plenty in a quadrupled recipe.  I also added a bit of white pepper and fresh ground pepper.  It was DELICIOUS!

text:
I loved it!  I did cut down on the sugar and used malt vinegar instead of white (I don't know why!). I used the salt to dry out the slaw mix a bit since I won't be serving this until tomorrow.  Instead of poppy seeds I added a little celery salt and fresh ground pepper.  I know this sounds strange but hubby and I both love sliced green olives in our slaw!  It adds a little bit of zip and most people like it after they try it.  I would imagine that this would be great on a bbq pork sandwich like they make in the south. I think I'm going to be making more slaw in the future.  Thanks for the recipe Sandi!!!

text:
I accidentally got a 2.5 oz package of coleslaw mix at the store, so I just used less of everything (like 1/4 cup of sugar instead of a 1/2 cup) I used 1/3 cup of Miracle Whip, 1 tbz of veggie oil, the original 1 tbs of vinegar, but all I had was white wine vinegar, and the 1/4 tbs of salt, ommitting the poppy seeds since my bf works for the government and poppy seeds would show up on a drug test. I added a green bell pepper finely diced. The flavor of the dressing is awesome, and I know that next time I will remember to get a 16 oz bag of slaw mix and I will follow the recipe exactly except for adding some green bell pepper...

SHERMON

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A 4.5 would better describe my rating.  I'm not a big fan of cole slaw in general but this is pretty good.  Everyone else at the party really enjoyed it.  It is a little on the sweet side as far as coleslaw goes. I really like the poppy seeds and the 2nd time I made the recipe I added celery seeds too. I thought there was a bit too much dressing and in the future I will add half the dressing (all the poppy seeds), let it sit for 2 hours and adjust the dressing from there. I had a big problem w/extra dressing the 1st time I had this because my bag of cole slaw mix was only 14 oz so check and make sure what size bag you have. Just made again (8/2011) and I still like and had none to put away when the party was over.  This time I did swap out some cabbage for broccoli slaw mix and nobody was the wiser!  I make the dressing and add sparingly, you always add more just before serving but you don't want it too drippy.

text:
This is my kind of slaw!  When I was a child I ate a bunch of sugar and mayo as my mother was preparing slaw and got really sick.  Never ate slaw again for probably 25 years.  Now I'm very picky about my slaw and this recipe is my favorite.  I buy the shredded slaw packages and then even cut it down more finely to get just the right texture.  Also, I often cut the recipe back to better serve two people and it works great.  It does taste like what you get out.

text:
I made a lot of modifications, but it was great!  (1) Mayo instead of Miracle Whip (2) Dollop of Sour Cream instead of Vegetable Oil (3) Less sugar (~1/3 cup) (4) More vinegar (~2 Tbsp) (5) Celery Seed instead of Poppy Seed  It's not science, I just threw things together until it looked right and this was about what I used.  Turned out great, I think this is a very flexible recipe!

text:
This coleslaw is easy to prepare and is delicous!  The only change I made, based on the recommendations of other feedback, was I substituted mayonaisse instead of miracle whip and I cut back on the sugar by about half.  After tasting it, it definitely would have been WAY too sweet with all of that sugar.  Half is about all you need and it is still sweet :-)  Enjoy, this recipe is a keeper!

text:
I recently became a fan of slaw mainly because I live in the south now, and we do a lot of BBQ's. I decided to look here for a recipe since the store bought garbage is way to sweet most of the time, or too soggy. This is easily a 5 star recipe! I've made it 3 times in 3 weeks. I took the advise of many and reduced the sugar amount slightly. Do yourself a favor and make sure you use the poppy seeds! I've made it both ways, and prefer to have them in it. Simple, inexpensive, and delicious!

country:

text:
I use allrecipes, all the time. And this is the first time I've ever rated a 5-star recipe lower than that. Have to admit I was somewhat disappointed in this recipe.  To be fair - I used Mayo instead of Miracle Whip because that's what my family prefers, but I think it would have tasted MUCH better with Miracle Whip. I also reduced the sugar to a 1/4 cup because 1/2 seemed like way too much. What I got was a very plain tasting, somewhat dry pile of cabbage. =(  I suppose I'll probably try it again - w/out variation to the recipe - but at this point I'm just not thrilled with it. UPDATE 45/1/10 - I tried this recipe again - making it exactly as noted and it was FANTASTIC!! Best cole slaw I've ever had. Use Miracle Whip (even if you don't like it) and the full amount of sugar - you WON'T be disappointed!

userID:
3987122
Display Name:
LiLGarnsey
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/327972.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! I HATE cole slaw, but I made this for my fiance and he made me try it...and I LOVED it!!! It's the only cole slaw I will eat now!! I use low fat or fat free may instead of Miracle Whip, 1/3 cup Splenda sugar substitute instead of 1/2 cup sugar, and I add about 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Sometimes I leave out the onions (a lot of people in my family don't like onions, but if I do add the onions, I use Sweet Vidalia onions). I usually just shred my own cabbage and carrots - saves me money!! ALDI stores usually sell a head of cabbage for around 99 cents and a bag of baby carrots for 99 cents also. I shred up about 2 cups cabbage and then I use my cheese grater to shred up 6 baby carrots, YUMMMMY!! I try to plan Chinese food for later in the week when I make this recipe - that way I can use the remainder of the head of cabbage shredded up in egg rolls and stir fry!

Oh man, oh man, oh man!! This slaw is delicious!!! I wanted to try it first, and if it's this good now, I can't wait to eat it again later!! I used fat free mayo instead of Miracle Whip because that's what I had. I also used olive oil instead of vegetable and omitted the poppy seeds because I didn't have any. I only used 3/8 cup of sugar because I like my slaw more on the tangy side. Even at that, I thought it was a tad too sweet for my taste. I added some more vinegar and a bit more mayo to mellow it out. Next time, I will try 1/4 cup sugar and see where that takes me. Even still, I gotta give this recipe 5 stars because it's THAT good! Thanks!

text:
As Rachel Ray would say, YUM-O.  I made a few additions after reading the reviews.  I made a smaller amount of slaw and used 1 head of green cabbage instead of the bagged.  I added cut up broccoli florets, and only used 1/3 cup of mayo, since I saw reviews that said it was a bit soggy, and I don't like my coleslaw very wet.  I used mayo instead of miracle whip (because I saw that the MW added sweetness), 1/4 c. of sugar, rice wine vinegar instead of white, and about a teaspoon of deli mustard for some uumph.  Delish, and the perfect amount of sweetness for me.  Obviously I made changes, but outside of the sweetness, the recipe itself is great.  I think it just depends on how sweet/wet you like your coleslaw.  Will make, again and again!

Very good coleslaw! It was too sweet for me also as it was, so I cut the sugar back to 1/4c and added 2 Tablespoons rice wine vinegar. I didn't have poppy seed or celery seed, so I used a pinch of celery salt, in addition to the regular salt (cut back a bit on the regular) and then a good dose of fresh ground black pepper. Let sit in the fridge fot 2 1/2 hours, and then ate with dinner. YUM!!! Added another 1/2 bag of slaw to the left overs and it was perfect again the next day. Thanks for a great recipe.

This is awesome cole slaw.  I made it the first time exact and it was too sweet as others have said.  I usually see recipes that others think are too sweet and I think they are fine but this was just a little too much.  I used the 1/2 meas. cup and just didn't fill it all the way, just guessed how much to leave out on the sugar.  Other than that perfect.  I also added small pieces of pineapple, grapes and golden raisins, if you like fruity slaw this one is good to make additions.

I'll have to go with 3 stars on this one.  The flavor was pretty good, but this a VERY sweet slaw, which I thought I liked, but it was way too much for me! I do agree that this gets very "wet" as it sits, but that is just the nature of cabbage and salt.

text:
I thought this was a great slaw.  I grew up in the deep south, and southern-style food is a big deal there.  If you do it wrong, especially a staple like cole slaw, they'll let you know by not eating it off their plate!  I made this and thought it was perfect...didn't use poppy seeds (didn't have any).  But the onion gives it a nice added flavor to it, and I added about 1/2 tsp more vinegar for more tart, used olive oil instead of veg oil, and I love the end result.  Made this to put on top of homemade bbq pulled pork I'm making in my crockpot today.  I can't wait to top my bbq pork sandwich with this.  TRUE southerners add cole slaw to the top of their bbq pork, in a sandwich. The combination of the creamy/tart flavor with your bbq pork sandwich is simply delicious!  Thanks for the recipe, I'll be holding onto this one.  A True Southerner's Stamp of Approval!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I got this recipe in order to save on the costly store-bought slaw dressing brand that I use.  It was finding it hard to continue to pay that price to have a good slaw dressing.  I tried it the first time and found that it works with modifications.  My husband likes a little tartness to his dressing so I reduced the sugar content and increased the vinegar.  After the modifications, I now make this in batches so that I can store the dressing in the fridge so I don't have to always make up a single batch.  Do yourself a favor, and try the recipe and adjust to your liking but, you can save money by using this recipe if you buy the store-bought brands.

text:
We have a local fish restaurant that is amazing, and many people that ate my slaw compared it to this restaurants!  The key is making it the night before or as early in the day as you can because the longer it sits, the thicker and creamier it gets. I add a few mustard seeds; I think they give it a little deeper flavor. It easily doubles for a crowd

This was really good.  I'll probably cut back the sugar a bit -- maybe just a little over a 1/4 cup and I have a major sweet tooth so let that be your guide.  I did not have poppy seeds but didn't miss them.  I did add two tablespoons of milk to this to thin out the dressing and coat everything nicely.  It gets better the longer it sits in the fridge.  My husband is a coleslaw connoisseur and this passed his test with flying colors.

text:
I have made this recipe MANY times.  The only changes I make are that I use real mayo instead of miracle whip, and I replace the poppy seeds with celery seed.  
When I first mix it, I always think that there is too much dressing.  However, after a few hours in the fridge or before serving, I drain the excess liquid and dressing and it turns out perfect.  So good!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this without the sugar or oil, and added about a teaspoon of hot sauce, and it was great. Not sure what the “chicken chain” slaw is supposed to taste like, but miracle whip Ian plenty sweet, so I can’t imagine how sweet this would be like with sugar. As far as oil, it just seems excessive. The dressing was a little thick, but once the veggies gave off some water (I tossed them in salt first), it was a great texture. PLEASE try it without all the sugar and oil! It’s  good coleslaw, and better for you!!

text:
The only coleslaw I feed my family! It’s the classic recipe. I don’t ever add poppy seeds, you’ll be good with half (or less) the amount of sugar, especially if using Miracle Whip, but I usually just use Hellman’s and still half the sugar! I eyeball the oil and vinegar but be careful doing that, it could definitely throw off the recipe! I make it hours before I plan to serve it and the flavors meld into some creamy and delicious coleslaw!
