text:
I know people don't like for you to change the recipe and rate it, but the website isn't allowing me to make a note of what I did so I'll have to do it here.  Sorry!
Instead of salad dressing, I used about 1/2 c of mayo and about 1/4 c of sour cream, 1/3 c sugar (instead of 1/2c), I skipped the veg. oil, and the onions and the poppy seeds and just used onion powder and black pepper.  It is AMAZING!!!  I'm just eating it alone for my lunch.  Thanks for a great recipe.

I have made this a few times.  It is really restaurant quality.  I hardly ever have buttermilk on hand because I can only get in quarts then the rest spoils in the fridg.  I use a little light cream with  the mayo and it is just as creamy as with buttermilk.  I just up the vinegar a bit and the lemon and it is delicious.  You can also use cider vinegar in place of the white wine vinegar and it won’t make much difference.

The best cole slaw recipe I have found and have made it several times.  I suggest you follow the recipe as written even though the dressing may not seem to be "enough" and let the slaw soak/marinate overnight.  The cabbage and the dressing mixture will become more liquid and leave you with the amount  you expect.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I really enjoy this recipe, I have made it enough times to enjoy it more. 
Yes, I know we all hate hearing about the changed recipe but making it once as written and then taking advice from others really makes the recipe! So thank you others that have added your changes. 
As some others have done, I have used regular mayo and also used rice wine vinegar. I did cut the sugar down as the rice wine vinegar is a little sweet. I also added pineapple tidbits and dried cranberries and raisins.  I did not use poppy seeds, I don’t care for those in my slaw or oil.
 I definitely do not find this dry or too wet. You need to let it sit for a couple hours for it to blend all together.

Display Name:
xbassman

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Gave this recipe 5-stars even though I didn’t make it as written.
That said, using it as a guide, I made the best slaw I’ve ever tasted!

I didn’t measure anything, but tasted and adjusted.
 1st I omitted oil. (Didn’t see the point)
2nd I reduced sugar by 1/2. (Salad dressing is already sweet)
Then I replaced salt and poppy with celery salt.
(If you want more tang add more vinegar, more depth of flavor add more celery salt. A good bit of fresh ground pepper helps as well.)

Put in a container that you can drain off excess liquid because slaw mix will sweat out water after 4+ hours dressed.

Now I just make it an evening before I plan to eat some and drain it the next day.
Review:

I love this slaw recipe- turns out delicious each time. Make sure you have small diced onions and plenty of time to chill, and toss again right before serving. I serve this slaw on top of Slow Cooker Pulled Pork (allrecipe by Livie’s Mommy) and the combination is a hit in my family. Both recipes taste like they take much more time than they truly do- about 20 minutes total for me earlier in the day, and dinner is ready as soon as we get home that night.

text:
This is a great basic coleslaw recipe. You may want to cut the sugar or oil to taste. I prefer my slaw light on dressing, so I typically add twice the shredded cabbage and use one grated small sweet onion (about 1/2 a cup), and I drain the excess water after it’s chilled at least 2 hours. This slaw is a great side or topping to just about anything. Crunchy deliciousness worth keeping on hand all the time!

Awesome together, however, I did cut down my own recipe and added sugar to taste and came up with less than the recipe called for!  Perfect as a side dish!

text:
Everyone raves about this recipe!
A few modifications I've developed.
Double the onion
Cut the sugar to 1/4 c 
Double the poppy seeds.
Add a pinch or marjoram to give it a bit more flavour.

If you want to make a spicier version add some Montreal Steak Seasoning.  Particularly good when served with the sweeter BBQ items like pulled pork, etc.

text:
Too sweet. Definitely cut back on the sugar, since Miracle Whip is already sweetened mayonnaise.  Side note, this should absolutely NOT be included in a search for no mayo slaws, since it contains a mayonnaise.

However, if you're searching for a traditional slaw, here you go.  Cut back on the sugar and you're golden.  Also a bit more pepper is tasty.

This was amazing, only 4 stars because I tweaked it. I used Miracle Whip, which is plenty sweet, so I omitted the sugar. The only thing is that next time, I will pulse the cabbage mix  in the food processor to get it smaller, and the texture a little more "mushy."

text:
I must admit that I HATE cole slaw..  but I made it for a party. And this was my first attempt at making cole slaw, ever. I didn't have poppy seeds and used Duke's Mayo instead of Miracle  whip, and threw in more onions that it called for; otherwise, I followed the directions.  I made it the night before and was worried it wouldn't turn out.  The next day, it looks liked cole slaw was supposed to look. I tasted it and it was really good.  It was a huge hit and went perfectly with pulled BBQ chicken.   I will make this again!

I  have made this cole slaw 3 times now and have enjoyed it each time. The only adjustment I have made was using basic mayonnaise instead of a sweet salad dressing or Miracle Whip. I found the sugar content to be enough and it kept the recipe more basic and not overpowering with flavor. Personal preference:  I use a little less of its ingredients as well because I prefer my cole slaws less creamy. Wonderful recipe...especially with poppy's!

text:
I made it almost exactly as the recipe states. I cut down slightly on the mayo. Just because I simply don't like mayo. And I used real mayonnaise not miracle whip. I cut back slightly on the sugar. Added an extra tablespoon of white vinegar & a tablespoon of apple cider vinegar. We like it tangier than we do creamier. And I accidentally added more poopy seeds...the holes on the poppy seed shaker were bigger than I imagined! We used this to top a pulled pork bbq sandwich and it was fantastic. I will use this recipe every time I make coleslaw. Yummy!

text:
It's a good base.  I started with homemade mayo-  the flavor is so much better and no mystery ingredients.  I'm glad I listened to other reviewers and cut back the sugar.  Used only 1/4 cup and it was still way too sweet.   I kept increasing the vinegar until the balance was the way I like it-  probably 1/4 cup total.  I also increased the onion to about 1/4 cup as well and used 1 teaspoon celery seed instead of poppy.  It's already fantastic!  I can't wait to try it out on my family tomorrow!

text:
My hubby is VERY fussy about Coleslaw. He doesn't like onion in it but I do! Don't let the 2T diced onion bother you. Even my husband thought this slaw was delicious. Tx for a great recipe that I will use over & over & over. SO GOOD. Made with exact ingredients called for.  After saying that, my hubby & I  decided we want a little less sugar in next one (maybe 1/3C).  Also, I  did put only half of dressing on initially  (as suggested by one reviewer), refrigerated about 1 hr, then drained some of the juice. I then added the rest of dressing. EXCELLENT. After 28 yrs of marriage, I found a Coleslaw we both love. Tx so much. A keeper.

text:
This was very good if you like really sweet coleslaw (I do!). When I first mixed everything, there was hardly enough mayo-mixture to coat it. I was concerned, but left it as-is and put it in the fridge. When I took it out a couple of hours later, everything was positively dripping with the mixture! Not sure what happens in the fridge, but it definitely works out. This could likely be made with less sugar if you wanted to be healthier.

None
text:
Very good, but must be eaten by the next day - it gets too liquidy as it sits. I used a little less than 2/3 cup Miracle Whip and reduced the oil to 2 TBSP.  I took the suggestion of others and cut the sugar in half, and it was just sweet enough. I used celery seed instead of poppy (personal preference), and added about 1/8 tsp black pepper. Next time I will add a little more vinegar (and maybe try using apple cider vinegar), as I like my slaw a little more tangy.

text:
This is a delicious cole slaw recipe! Better than any fast food slaw. I did make a few changes after reading other reviews , just to suit my personal taste. I decreased the sugar to 1/3 cup, oil decreased to just 1 tbsp. and vinegar increased to 3 tbsp. I finely grated sweet onion. Mixed all ingredients and refrigerated over night. Gave everything a stir this morning and did a taste test...Yummy! Next time I make this, I will substitute celery seeds for the poppy seeds.

This is now my go to recipe for cole slaw. Yes, it is sweet, but isn't it supposed to be sweet? However, after it sits and draws the liquid out of the cabbage, it is very soupy.  To solve that, I increase the cabbage (or shredded cole slaw mix). Today I used two 16 ounce bags. It tastes fine and isn't runny.  It's perfect to take to a Father's Day picnic!

text:
Best cole slaw I ever made - really does taste like my favorite from KFC!  
I've made it since the first time, when I followed the recipe exactly as written.  These are the changes I now make to tweak it to my liking..... I think it only needs 1/4 c of sugar, and it's still plenty sweet, and I add a few more ounces of cabbage because I think it's just a bit much dressing for the amount of cabbage.  I absolutely love it!  Give it a try because it's so easy!   I use my Ninja food chopper to chop the cabbage with a  bit of carrot, and then empty it into a bowl.  Then I mix up the dressing in the chopper to mix everything easily and throughly before pouring it over the cabbage mix.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I HAVE to review this recipe.  I have never reviewed a recipe before, yet have used this site for years.  I had to chuckle that almost 1800 people had taken the time to review COLE SLAW!  However, make it I did for a family function.  I received compliment after compliment on it.  This amazed me.... I mean, Cole Slaw is Cole Slaw! I made it exactly as written.  I read multiple reviews, some suggested making it the night before, others cautioned against this. I chose to do both.  I mixed the dressing (and added the onions directly to the dressing) the night before.  I was a bit apprehensive as I poured it over the slaw a mere 3 hours before it was ready to be served, but it was perfect by serving time. I did change one thing.  I made it with half celery seed and half poppy seed.  I will be making this VERY easy dish many times in the future!

I used mayonnaise rather than Miracle Whip as well and it wasn't excessively sweet. Used a bit more than the recipe calls for, but I wasn't strict on the quantity of veggies. In any case, it turned out great. Added to my recipe box and this will be one I return to when I need some slaw.

region:

country:
None
text:
Best cole slaw I have ever made.  Such a great base recipe.  I tend to try to make things a little more on the healthy side so I made a few changes.  I used light Miracle Whip, I also replaced the oil with light sour cream.  I didn't have poppy seeds so I used celery seed and I cut the sugar to 1/3 cup and found that was plenty sweet enough.  I also used white rice wine vinegar as another reviewer suggested (I didn't have white vinegar on hand).  My boyfriend LOVED this recipe so much I made it twice in 2 days.  Definitely a keeper!!

text:
I have made this recipe many times in the past 3 or so months since I discovered it. I love it. I've made it exactly as written, and it's a delicious, 5-star recipe. However, I have developed my own twist. I always use a whole red onion because it's so pretty, olive oil, raw sugar and apple cider vinegar. To my family, these changes really make this recipe come alive. I also prefer to make it the day before and let it sit overnight, as the flavours are so much better the next day.

I don't care for poppy seeds, so I also used celery and did cut the amount of sugar (Splenda) in half. Any time a recipe calls for either mayo or Miracle Whip, I use half of each to cut down on an overwhelming taste. Both were "light" but the finished product tastes great. Making the dressing early and letting it marry before mixing in the slaw kept it from getting runny. Thanks so much for the recipe!

text:
I'll tell you what...I run a BBQ Catering business & I had about given up on serving slaw. I refuse to buy ready made and I just could not find a recipe that I liked. This slaw has been a bit of a lesson for me...as for myself, I can hardly eat it...it is waaay too sweet.

The customers on the other hand, have attacked it. I have served it 4 times now and always get lots of positive comments...and none left. I actually watched one guy come back for thirds.  'Nuff said:-)

The last batch I did cut back the sugar by about a third. Still sweet but nobody complained.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3638847.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is perfect! You MUST use miracle whip (or store equivalent) as the recipe calls for in order for this to turn out perfect, mayo will not cut it! I have made it dozens of times and it is always a hit! I have also used a broccoli slaw instead of cabbage for this recipe with wonderful results. I rarely add the poppy seeds to keep this recipe more "budget-friendly", and I dont really miss them. I have also omitted the onion before for an anti-onion dinner guest, or when I didnt have it on hand, and though it still turns out well you can tell its missing that little something. We cannot have pulled pork or fried chicken at my house without this slaw! I also LOVE it on a turkey sandwich! YUM!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-04-30T07:37:06.737
helpfulCount:

With a few tweaks this recipe has been a huge hit in my family. Some do not like the onion but like the onion flavor. So, I thoroughly mix in plenty of onion powder with the slaw to start and let it sit for awhile. I double the recipe accept that I put in under a half a cup of sugar. A half cup was still to sweet for us even after doubling everything else.

text:
Fixed this yesterday for a small family get together and it was a HUGE hit!!
My husband, who despises coleslaw usually actually said to me that this was something he would actually eat on a regular basis! O_O
Everyone gave it rave reviews and said how good it was. One person even scraped the bowl to get every last piece of it that was left. 
I did make a couple of minor changes that I don't think made too much of a difference in the end result. I used celery seed since I couldn't find poppy. I also used about 2-3 tbs less sugar, apple cider vinegar instead of white, and light flavor olive oil instead of veg.
This was great. Wish I had made 2 batches instead of just the one. I will def make this again!

text:
My family loves this recipe- even my daughter who is not a coleslaw fan. I did make a few minor alterations. I replaced the dressing with Duke's low fat mayonnaise. I cut the sugar in half, added an additional 1/4 teaspoon salt and 3 additional Tablespoons vinegar. I also added about 1/2 teaspoon fresh cracked pepper. The result was delicious and not too sweet with the perfect vinegar bite. Would highly recommend!

text:
This was an absolutely perfect for Sunday night football! We served it along pulled pork sliders, but the coleslaw was the surprise hit of the night. We had a large group, so I double the recipe. Like others suggested, I cut back the sugar some (used apx 3/4 cup) and for my crew, I added a pack of diced bacon to the dressing before mixing with the cabbage. It was delicious, and even with doubling the recipe there were hardly any leftovers. I got several requests to pass along the recipe to other families, and will be making again for sure! :)

text:
I do not like most cole slaws.  However, this recipe is fantastic!  I could eat it all day long!  I would recommend that you reduce the sugar in half if you don't want it too sweet.  I also took out one tablespoon of oil.  It will seem as if you don't have enough dressing for all that cole slaw but while it sits, it pulls some fluid out of the cabbage and turns out creamy and perfect.  Please try this recipe as it is a winner for me!

Everyone loves this recipe!
I make a few changes
#1 - i always double it
#2 - i do not add the onion
#3 - i add apple cider vinegar and rice wine vinegar in place of white vinegar
#4 - i add 1/2 teaspoon celery seed
Most importantly i use regular mayo, not miracle whip.
It is a hit every time i make it!!

text:
I made this for my husband this evening and he really liked it. I omitted the onion, used celery seed instead of poppy seed and used red wine vinegar instead of white. I personally do not like coleslaw so I am going on his reaction and he pretty much ate the whole bowl for dinner. He suggested adding 1/8 to 1/4 more miracle whip to thicken it up a little. I will definitely make this again for him :-D
*addendum: I make the slaw sauce early and let it set in the refrigerator for several hours, about an 1/2 hour before serving I add the slaw mix well (I use a covered bowl and shake) put back in the refrigerator until ready to serve. It stays crispier and doesn't get limp and yucky

text:
Probably about a 4.5, a tad sweet even with changes. I used 1/4 c. Splenda, but could probably cut that back to about 1/3 cup. Because it was so sweet initially, I added about 1/4 cup more mayo. I probably wouldn't have added it if I had cut back on the Splenda. Added 2 tsp minced onions (would have used fresh if I had any) and added an additional 1/4 tsp vinegar. Also liberally sprinkled on some ground black pepper. My husband doesn't like coleslaw, but had seconds of this one. He thought it was really good. I didn't have poppy seeds, so didn't use any.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made cabbage slaw once in my life and that was from a kit. I test tried this for a upcoming party. I took some advice from other people on tweeking this recipe. I'm not a fan of Miracle Whip so I used 1/3 cup of regular mayo and 1/3 cup of sour cream. Omitted the oil, used 1/3 cup of sugar, Walla Walla sweet onion, and rice wine vinegar. The sauce was really good. After tossing the sauce with the slaw, I tasted it and I almost couldn't stop eating it. But I did. I refrigerated it for just over an hour and had it as a side dish with sloppy Joes. My husband dislikes cabbage slaw but he enjoyed this one. It tastes better the long it sits in the fridge. It was a but soupy. I'll take someone's suggestion where you put half the sauce, toss, refrigerate for over an hour to sweat the cabbage, drain then add the rest of the sauce before serving.

5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We've made this twice.  The first time we followed the recipe exactly and it is very tasty, like what you get at restaurants.  The second time, we substituted 2 Tablespoons of apple juice and 1 Tablespoon of oil instead of 3 Tablespoons of oil (I thought that would be too much oil).  We also substituted apple cider vinegar for white vinegar and that resulted in a stronger vinegar taste.  Next time, I will split the vinegar amount between the white / apple cider vinegar.  The apple flavor is surprisingly tasty in this slaw.  Overall, the family loves this recipe and we'll make it often.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-05-31T20:09:25.053
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
9172614
Display Name:
Cheryl King
isPro:
False
followersCount:
57
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
98
favoritesCount:
382
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6246071.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did make a couple of changes to this recipe.  Here they are  – the first changes I made were celery seed instead of poppy seed.  I used white wine vinegar as opposed to white, because I only use white vinegar to clean with, I never cook with it.  I used half mayo/half miracle whip, because I like the flavor of each, and think it adds body when making dressings to use both.  I also used a chopped green onion, because I had some for a different recipe, and I prefer the milder flavor.  Then  I reduced the sugar to 1/3 cup.   I also used olive oil instead of vegetable oil, and only used about a tablespoon of it instead of 3. Finally, I took gatorgirl’s suggestion to only use half of the dressing, let the slaw rest for an hour, drain the slaw, and top with the remaining dressing.  I thought it was a brilliant way to reduce the watery quality of the slaw.  I made a little extra dressing to make up for what would drain out.  The problem, and perhaps this has something to do with the dry climate here in New Mexico, was that after only an hour, almost none of the moisture had been removed from the slaw.  I went ahead and added the remaining dressing and the following day, the slaw was runnier than I liked.  I think the solution to this would have been to let the slaw rest overnight with only ½ the dressing, drain, and to add the final dressing just before serving.  At any rate, the slaw was very delicious.  I have found a recipe I will use from now on.
Review:
Rating:
5

My family does not like slaw so I rarely ever make it but I was asked to make it for a funeral so I was thankful for this recipe.  I used my Kitchen-aide to shred the carrots and cabbage since I needed a lot and didn't want to pay more for the slaw mix. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
*****

The reviews are extremely helpful in this recipe.  Less sugar, but too little and the onion becomes overpowering.  I'd suggest a half to 2/3rds of a cup when using Miricle Whip. I added in a few turns of ground pepper and used half a sweet onion. I like it creamy but if you like a bit more crunch, add the radishes and slowly add in the Miricle Whip until you get the desired 'crunch factor' happening.  Great Slaw!

text:
A serious pregnancy craving for coleslaw lead me to this recipe. I've consumed coleslaw maybe a handful of times in my life and have never made it. SUPER RECIPE! I could have eaten half of this when it was freshly made (I liked the crisper cabbage and more vinegary flavor) but my husband who is a bit of a coleslaw critic thought it was perfect once chilled. I did not use poppy seeds, 1/3rd cup sugar, and used canola instead of vegetable oil.

text:
This is a great recipe, with some changes: Use only 1/4 cup of sugar if you want a salad not a dessert. 1/2 cup sugar is way too much. I used my own homemade mayonnaise instead of dressing. I increased the salt to 1/2 teaspoon. I added 3 tablespoons of yogurt and omit the oil! If you follow the way I modified this recipe then you will have a bowl of cloeslaw much much better tasting than those fried chicken restaurants. Enjoy!

This recipe was amazing. I have a very hard time getting my kids to eat veggies, period. This was the first thing to disappear off their plates at dinner. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really good! I grew up in a "Friday night fish fry" community so I have tried my fair share of cole slaws. I have tried lots of "copycat recipes" but none hold a candle to this. I read reviews and took some of the suggestions and added some of my own. I only make up a 1/2 batch at a time so it doesn't get runny with just three of us eating it.
My changes were using mayo, 1/3 cup sugar (still plenty sweet), celery seed, olive oil instead of just vegetable oil and the oddest thing was to add cauliflower pieces. I did this on a whim because the first time I made it I had too much dressing on it. My teenager liked that addition. I feel that it ads even another healthy element to the cabbage, plus I don't load on the dressing. This is a keeper!

text:
This recipe is a good starting point, but I have NEVER made it as written. I follow Atkins (low-carb) so I use real mayonnaise instead of carbier Miracle Whip and granular Splenda in place of sugar. The first time I made it, I used poppy seeds as written and halved the amount of sweetener. I didn't like the poppy seeds and the coleslaw was too sweet. This time, I used 1/4 teaspoon celery seeds instead of poppy, added several grinds of fresh black pepper, and only used 2 tablespoon of sweetener. Next time I'll try 1/2 teaspoon celery seeds and maybe a touch more sweetener.

text:
This tasted fantastic! I made it two different ways: one with salad dressing (Miracle Whip) and real mayo. I read all the reviews and was worried it may come out too sweet. I mixed the dressing mixture first then adding sugar just a little bit at a time to taste. I ended up using 1/3 c and it was perfect for our tastes. I will say though the Miracle Whip one is sweeter than the real mayo one so that could be the key. I also used celery seed instead of poppy seeds mainly because that's what I had on hand. My mom who thought it was a silly idea for me to make this and said wouldn't eat it absolutely loved it and told me I had to make it more often. This will become a bbq staple!

The first time was exactly as called for. Far, far and away too sweet, for me anyway. I now make this using mayo and 1/4 cup of Splenda.  And, as others suggested, gotta have the celery seed. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this cole slaw several times and my family loves it!  I just made a few changes/additions and am always asked to bring it to family gatherings, potlucks, etc.  I used 1/2 c. chopped sweet onion(vadalia, if in season) and added 1/2 c. chopped fresh green peppers.  I also add a cup of already packaged shreaded carrots.  As far as the mayo, I used 1/2 Lite Miracle Whip and 1/2 Lite Hellman's totalling 2/3 cup.  I also cut back on the sugar to 1/4 c. and cut back on the canola oil using only 1 TBSP instead of 3 TBSP. Ground pepper to taste.  End result is an awesome and tangy coleslaw for a year-round side dish to any event or holiday!!
Review:

2440111
Display Name:
Annette

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an absolutely delicious and easy slaw recipe to make! I am making this recipe again for tomorrow's Easter dinner. I did make a couple revisions to suit our family's taste. I used the recommended amounts of bagged cole slaw (we enjoy the the tri color mix with green and red cabbage and carrots) and replaced the onion with three green onions (scallions) and finely diced the white part and cut about three inches of each green top in 1/8 inches pieces with a kitchen scissors. It adds even more color and a milder onion flavor than some regular onions. The "dressing/sauce" ingredients I halved since we don't care for extremely juicy slaw, and it saves some calories for those health conscientious guests. If you make it the night before you plan to serve it, there seems to be plenty of moisture to give it great flavor. It is a bit sweet, but another option would be to cut down the amount of sugar by 1-2 tablespoons or increase the vinegar by 1-2 teaspoons.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-04-10T21:41:29.357
helpfulCount:

text:
This coleslaw was very tasty with our BBQ last night. I used all the dressing ingredients as written (except subbed veganaise for the mayo) and rather than buying a bag of wilted shredded cabbage for $1.79 (!) I bought a small head of cabbage for .66 and shredded it myself, adding 3 grated carrots. This may have cut down on the sweetness a little because I'm pretty sure I ended up with more slaw than I would have if I had used the pre-sliced veggies. Either way, very tasty. The boyfriend loved it too.

YUM!  This is quite possibly the best slaw I've ever eaten....and it is so much easier to make than many out there.  I just made this today for a neighborhood block party and it is DELICIOUS!  Definitely don't forget to allow 2+ hours for it to set.  It is a completely different dish once it does. Display Name:
SUIW

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1505043.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful coleslaw recipe! Don't tweak it or change it, don't add more sugar or mayo, etc. Leave the recipe as is. The trick is to make it well in advance and let the coleslaw chill in the fridge. A couple hours is fine, but ideally you want it to sit in the fridge overnight to let the flavors meld together. It will all come together once chilled and allowed to sit for some time. I made it as a sidedish with pork ribs, and the men couldn't get over that it was homemade coleslaw. It tasted like, but just as good as KFC, if not better. I had mine chilled in the fridge all day, and at the end of the meal there were no leftovers.

text:
Everyone raved about this coleslaw!  I used  reduced-fat mayo instead of Miracle Whip (MW is just too tangy for me).  I also used half rice vinegar and half apple cider vinegar to add more flavor.  I reduced the sugar to 1/3 C and added 1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper.  Fabulous - tasted just like the coleslaw you get at fast food fried chicken places.  I will definitely be making this again.

text:
My mom made this when I came to visit last week.  She had made this for their friends who came to visit & told me how they raved and raved about how good it was, and they were right!!  It tastes very similar to KFC or Lee's.  She said it was so easy to make and not to be alarmed when you're done mixing it up and it seems too dry.  Apparently cabbage releases water and that's why you must let it chill for 2 hours, or overnight as she does.  Very good recipe.  I look forward to making it myself to take to the next function I'm invited to!
